summarize.original: A 72-year-old female with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), hypertension, and osteoporosis presented to the emergency department with worsening shortness of breath and a persistent productive cough over the past two weeks. She reported increased fatigue and reduced exercise tolerance. On examination, she was tachypneic with a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute, had bilateral wheezing on auscultation, and an oxygen saturation of 88% on room air. A chest X-ray showed increased bronchovascular markings but no focal consolidation. Laboratory tests revealed an elevated white blood cell count and C-reactive protein. She was diagnosed with an acute exacerbation of COPD, likely secondary to a bacterial infection. She was started on nebulized bronchodilators, systemic corticosteroids, and empirical antibiotic therapy with azithromycin. Over the next 48 hours, her symptoms improved, and she was discharged on an optimized COPD maintenance regimen, including long-acting bronchodilators, inhaled corticosteroids, and a short course of oral prednisone. She was advised to follow up with her pulmonologist in two weeks and was given instructions on proper inhaler technique and pulmonary rehabilitation exercises

sanitize.original:
Patient Name: John Doe
Age: 58
Diagnosis: Acute Ischemic Stroke

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with sudden onset right-sided weakness and slurred speech. On arrival, he had a National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) score of 8. A CT scan ruled out hemorrhage, and an MRI confirmed an acute ischemic stroke in the left middle cerebral artery (MCA) territory. He received intravenous thrombolysis with alteplase within 2 hours of symptom onset, showing partial improvement.

During his hospital stay, he was monitored in the stroke unit, where he received supportive care, physical therapy, and secondary stroke prevention measures. His blood pressure was managed with antihypertensives, and he was initiated on dual antiplatelet therapy with aspirin and clopidogrel. Echocardiography revealed no evidence of a cardioembolic source, and carotid Doppler imaging showed moderate stenosis of the right internal carotid artery.
